results.title: Clothing and fashion: a history
results.brief_description: The evolution of fashions in clothing, from Egyptian times until today, is perceived in amusing animation. The choice to cover the body with unnatural materials has been made largely for social status, conformity and vanity. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Clothing
results.creator_credit: ERPI Classroom Films, Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and John Barnes
results.brief_description: Primitive peoples used the materials available in their immediate environment from which to make clothing for themselves. This film traces the development of the textile arts through hand-processes of various nationalities to modern mass-production methods of an industrialised economy. The effect of climate and environment on the materials and modes of dress, and the effects of modern mass-production, coupled with the development of transport and communication methods, are studied. The clothing from industrialised countries is shown to be becoming increasingly widespread throughout the world.

results.title: Clothespeak
results.creator_credit: Arbor Films, Fiz Oliver and Margaret Williams
results.brief_description: Looks at established youth style groups such as Mods, Skinheads, Punks and the New Romantics. Illustrates the importance of style to such groups and aims to eliminate preconceptions about people whose appearance is out of the ordinary. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Clotheslines
results.brief_description: A poetic documentary which focuses on laundry as an aspect of women’s lives and work in the home. The film is composed largely of tales and memories, and through the acts of hanging, folding, arranging, ironing and placing laundry in drawers, “Clotheslines” demonstrates how these have become symbolic actions for mothering, living properly and, most of all, providing a sense of security.

results.title: Clothes around the world
results.brief_description: Illustrates the variation from country to country in the style of clothes worn and how it is influenced by climate, available materials and the individueal preferences of the people who wear them.

results.title: Cloth: fiber to fabric
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and William Kay
results.brief_description: Cotton, wool and silk are natural fibres, although grown in different ways; synthetic fibres such as rayon and nylon are created by chemical processes. However, all can be woven into cloth on power looms or knitting machines, and the fabric produced can be used for flameproof firemens’ suits, seat belts and parachutes as well as common articles like clothing, rugs, towels.

results.title: Closet space
results.creator_credit: Cindigo Vision, Karen Taylor and Colleen Farrelly
results.brief_description: Parents with gay children share their experiences and feelings, fears and joys on discovering that their child is gay. A parents supporting parents Flag (South Australia), which aims to bring families together and break down the barriers of homophobia. An honest and open discussion piece which challenges and debates notions of heterosexism as parents and children share their personal stories.

results.title: Closed Mondays
results.brief_description: In a combination of graphics and three-dimensional clay figures, a little man discovers the world of art. He sees an open door and wanders through into an art exhibition. Paintings come alive and move around him as he watches. As he turns to go, he himself is put on a pedestal and bronzed. A 1975 Academy Award winner. Suitable for upper primary, lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: Close your eyes and hold your stomach
results.brief_description: In a survey of some of the ways Australian children are discovering their own kind of theatre, this film focuses on a touring children’s theatre company, the Pageant Theatre in Education, which tours Australian schools. School children are invited by the actors to participate in the production of each play and their responses influence the shape of the play. Children of different age groups are observed creating fantasy worlds on the one hand and recreating political and social issues on the other. Made with the assistance of the Australian Film & Television School. Narrated by Robert Bruning.

results.title: Close harmony
results.brief_description: An inspiring documentation of the work of music teacher Arlene Symons in bringing together a chorus of children from the 1979-1980 class of the Friends School in Brooklyn, New York and the senior chorus from the Council Centre for Senior Citizens, Brooklyn. Three months of separate rehearsals took place, and a pen pal program set up between the two groups. A week before the concert, the groups came together.
